planet.name: Mars

generalInfo.description: Mars – the fourth planet from the Sun – is a dusty, cold, desert world with a very thin atmosphere. This dynamic planet has seasons, polar ice caps, extinct volcanoes, canyons, and weather.
generalInfo.namesake: Mars was named by the ancient Romans for their god of war because its reddish color was reminiscent of blood. Other civilizations also named the planet for this attribute – for example, the Egyptians called it 'Her Desher,' meaning 'the red one.'
generalInfo.age: Mars is often nicknamed 'The Red Planet' due to its surface appearance caused by iron oxidation.

potentialForLife.description: Scientists don't expect to find living things currently thriving on Mars. Instead, they're looking for signs of life that existed long ago, when Mars was warmer and covered with water.
potentialForLife.climateChangeImpact: Mars' thin atmosphere and cold temperatures make it currently inhospitable to life as we know it.

sizeAndDistance.rank: Seventh largest planet in the solar system

orbitAndRotation.leapYearExplanation: Mars does not experience leap years, but its orbit period influences its longer years.
orbitAndRotation.seasonalEffects: The tilt causes Mars to have seasons, with varying lengths due to its elliptical orbit.

moons.description: Mars has two small moons, Phobos and Deimos, which are irregularly shaped and likely captured asteroids.
moons.origin: Phobos and Deimos are thought to be captured objects from the asteroid belt.
moons.rankInSize: Phobos is the larger of the two.

planet.rings: Mars has no rings. However, in about 50 million years, Phobos may break apart to form a dusty ring.

formation.description: Mars formed about 4.5 billion years ago from the same disk of gas and dust that formed the other planets in the solar system.

layers.name: Core
layers.description: Possibly made of iron, nickel, and sulfur, and is about 1,500 kilometers in radius.

layers.name: Mantle
layers.description: A rocky layer of silicates that may have generated volcanic activity in the past.

layers.name: Crust
layers.description: A thin outer layer primarily composed of iron-rich basaltic rock.

surface.features: Mars has the tallest volcano in the solar system, Olympus Mons, and the longest canyon, Valles Marineris. It also has polar ice caps and vast plains.
surface.oceanCoverage: No liquid water currently exists, but ancient riverbeds and lakebeds suggest a wetter past.
surface.volcanicActivity: Mars' volcanic activity is believed to have ceased billions of years ago, though it shaped much of its surface.

composition.other: Traces of oxygen, water vapor, and methane

atmosphere.protection: Mars' thin atmosphere provides little protection from radiation and meteor impacts.

magnetosphere.cause: Mars lacks a global magnetic field due to its cooling core, but localized magnetic fields are present in certain regions.
magnetosphere.effects: The lack of a magnetosphere exposes Mars' surface to higher radiation levels.
magnetosphere.polarityReversal: Mars' magnetic field is no longer active, so polarity reversals do not occur.
